questions.text: Hyperextension at MCP joint and flexion at Interphalangeal joints in hands is suggestive of palsy of
questions.solution:
The deformity explained is the above question is CLAW HAND- seen in ulnar nerve injury

Ulnar nerve innervates medial 2 lumbricals

Action of lumbricals: flexion at metacarpophalangeal joints and extension at Interphalangeal joints

So if lumbricals are paralysed due to ulnar nerve injury_ it leads to Hyperextension at MCP joint and flexion at Interphalangeal joints- CLAW HAND

Reference: Maheshwari textbook of orthopedics 7th edition, pg no 63

questions.text: Identify the angle shown in the image
questions.solution:
For proper assessment of scoliosis, a full antero-posterior X-ray of the spine in supine and erect positions, plus a lateral view are necessary.

Severity of the curve is measured by Cobb's angle - an angle between the line passing through the margins of the vertebrae at the ends of the curve

Option c) Ferguson angle (lateral sacral angle): The angle is measured by joining a line across the plane of the superior margin of the sacrum and a horizontal line.

Option b) Bohler’s angle and GIssane angle: used in fracture calcaneum, the Bohler’s angle is lowered in calcaneal fracture (Bohler-Lower) and Gissane angle is increased in calcaneal fracture

Option d) Bauman angle- also called humero capitellar angle

In cubitus varus: bauman angle is increased

In cubitus valgus: bauman angle is decreased

Reference: Maheshwari textbook of orthopedics 7th edition, pg no 281

questions.text: A patient presents with pain around base of thumb. There is inflammation around the 2 tendons marked in the image. Identify them
questions.solution:
Tendons in the given image are abductor pollicis longus (APL) and extensor pollicis brevis (EPB)

This is a condition characterised by pain and swelling over the radial styloid process. It results from inflammation of the common sheath of abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons.

On examination, the tenderness is localised to the radial styloid process. Pain is aggravated by adducting the thumb across the palm and forcing ulnar deviation and on asking the patient to perform radial deviation against resistance (Finkelstein's test). There may be a palpable thickening of the sheath.

Reference: Maheshwari textbook of orthopedics 7th edition, pg no 303

questions.text: A patient presents with deformity of the finger as shown in the picture. O\E its found that the PIP is involves but DIP is spared. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows swan neck deformity( flexion at DIP and extension at PIP) seen in rheumatoid arthritis

Rheumatoid arthritis mainly involves small joints (MCP joint, PIP joint) with sparing of DIP characteristic of rheumatoid arthritis

Hand changes in rheumatoid arthritis:

Option c) psoriatic arthritis

Hand changes in psoriatic arthritis:


  • Most commonly involves- DIP joint
  • Sausage digits
  • Opera glass hands (telescoping of fingers)
  • Arthritis mutilans
  • Pencil in cup deformity

Option a) osteoarthritis

Hand changes in osteoarthritis

  • PIP- Bouchard nodes
  • DIP- heberden node

Reference: Maheshwari textbook of orthopedics 7th edition, pg no 287

questions.text: Most commonly used drug for osteoporosis in a postmenopausal female is
questions.solution:
Treatment of osteoporosis

Problems of using bisphophonates:

  • Prolong fracture healing
  • Chronic use causes atypical fractures (subtrochanteric fractures of femur)

Prevention: by giving drug holiday (bisphosphiantes stopped after 5yr use and restarted after 2-3yrs bridged with teriperatide in absence of bisphophonates)

Reference: Maheshwari textbook of orthopedics 7th edition, pg no 309

questions.text: 55 years old female complains of chronic back ache. Her X-RAY is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
X-RAY spine features of osteoporosis:

  • Biconcave vertebrae
  • Cod fish vertebrae: The disc bulges into the adjacent vertebral bodies so that the disc becomes biconvex.
  • Fish mouth vertebrae
  • Lincoln log vertebrae

Option b) hurler’s syndrome: bullet shaped vertebrae

Option c) Paget’s disease: picture frame vertebrae, ivory vertebrae

Option d) renal osteodystrophy: rugger jersey spine vertebrae

Reference: Maheshwari textbook of orthopedics 7th edition, pg no 309

questions.text: A 4yr child while playing, suddenly pulled back her elbow from nanny's hand and started crying and not allowing anyone to touch the elbow. She is keeping the elbow extended and pronated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
PULLED ELBOW (NURSE MAID ELBOW)

This condition occurs in children between 2-5 years of age. The head of the radius is pulled partly out of the annular ligament when a child is lifted by the wrist. The child starts crying and is unable to move the affected limb.

The forearm lies in an attitude of pronation. There may be mild swelling at the elbow. It is not possible to see the subluxated head on an X-ray because it is still cartilaginous; X-rays are taken only to rule out any other bony injury.

Treatment: The head is reduced by fully supinating the forearm and applying direct pressure over the head of the radius. A sudden click is heard or felt as the head goes back to its place. The child becomes comfortable and starts moving his elbow almost immediately

Reference: Maheshwari textbook of orthopedics 7th edition, pg no 105

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Popeye’s sign: proximal rupture of biceps tension (long head)

Popeye sign is a pronounced bulging muscle in the distal aspect of the biceps region of the arm. It is clinically apparent with a complete long head of biceps tendon tear which causes distal migration of the long head of biceps muscle.

Reference: internet: website radiopaedia.org

questions.text: A patient received 48 hrs after fracture of femur presented with confusion and breathing difficulty. He is having PaO2 of 50. He was put on rebreathing unit and started maintaining SPO2 of 100%, but remains confused. Chest is clear. What is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
FAT EMBOLISM SYNDROME

This is one of the most serious complications, the essential feature being occlusion of small vessels by fat globules.

Causes: The fat globules may originate from bone marrow or adipose tissue. Fat embolism is more common following severe injuries with multiple fractures and fractures of major bones. The pathogenesis of the syndrome is not clear, but it seems likely that two events occur: (i) release of free fatty acids (by action of lipases on the neutral fat), which induces a toxic vasculitis, followed by platelet-fibrin thrombosis; and (ii) actual obstruction of small pulmonary vessels by fat globules.

Consequences: Symptoms are evident a day or so after the injury. Presenting features are in the form of two, more or less distinct types: (i) cerebral; and (ii) pulmonary. In the cerebral type, the patient becomes drowsy, restless and disoriented and gradually goes into a state of coma. In the pulmonary type, tachypnoea and tachycardia are the more prominent features. The other common feature of fat embolism is a patechial rash, usually on the front of the neck, anterior axillary folds, chest or conjunctiva. If untreated, and sometimes despite treatment, the patient develops respiratory failure and dies.

Diagnosis: In a case with multiple fractures, early diagnosis may be possible by strong suspicion. In addition to the classic clinical features, signs of retinal artery emboli (striate haemorrhages and exudates) may be present. Sputum and urine may reveal the presence of fat globules. X-ray of the chest may show a patchy pulmonary infiltration (snow storm appearance). Blood PO 2 of less than 50 mmHg may indicate impending respiratory failure.

GURD’s criteria used for fat embolism syndrome

Treatment: This consists of respiratory support, heparinisation, intravenous low molecular weight dextran (Lomodex-20) and corticosteroids. An intravenous 5 percent dextrose solution with 5 percent alcohol helps in emulsification of fat globules, and is used by some.

Reference: Maheshwari textbook of orthopedics 7th edition, pg no 43

questions.text: Patient aged 30 years presented with swelling around knee. Aspirate shows giant cells and mononuclear cells. Most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Giant cell tumor:

AGE (YR): 20-40 Slight female predominance

SITE: Distal femur>Proximal tibia>Distal radius

PRESENTATION: Pain, Pathologic fracture (10%-30%), Egg shell cracking sound on tapping the lesion is heard

IMAGING:

Eccentrically located in epiphysis

Purely radiolucent (no matrix formation) Soap bubble appearance

Usually no rim of reactive bone

Abuts subchondral bone

May exhibit cortical destruction with soft tissue extension

Metaphyseal in skeletally immature patients

HISTOLOGY:

Multinucleated giant cells in sea of mononuclear cells

Nuclei of mononuclear stromal cells identical to nuclei of giant cells- these are the actual tumor cells and not the giant cells. These stromal cells produce RANk ligands which stimulate the osteoclast further causing destruction of the bone

TREATMENT:

Extended curettage Resection if residual bone stock inadequate with phenol or liquid nitrogen

Consider radiation for spinal/ sacral tumors Resection of pulmonary metastases

Reference: Maheshwari ortho 7th edition page no 232
